captions.text:
MIKE MUSTO: If you were to
open the garage of most

grandfathers, the odds of you
seeing a Cadillac wouldn't be
that far-fetched.

You might see an El Dorado
or maybe a Seville.

But a '64 Deville with blown
big block, that's not too

common-- well, except for today
on "Big Muscle," where

we've got the coolest
one around.

Now first and foremost, what
you have to remember about

this car is that it's
a Cadillac.

What that means is that
it's a luxury
car, first and foremost.

So look at the details
in this car.

Look at the fact that the
leather seats are
beautiful ox blood.
They're nicely cushioned.
They feel great.
Yes, it's a bench seat.
But remember, this was 1964.

Buckets weren't really
around yet,
especially in luxury cars.

Stuff like the stainless
around the dash.

It's not-- it's not crazy over
the top, but it really gives

you a sense of success and
luxury, which, back then,
Cadillac was all about.

I mean, from the 1930s up
until the early 1970s,
Cadillac was the car to own.

I mean, yes, you could
own a Rolls.

Yes, you could've owned
a Mercedes.

But if you were American, and
you wanted the best America

had to offer, this is
what you bought.
And there's a reason.

Look at the stainless bright
work around the door, around

the steering wheel, and around
the door bezels.

I mean, power-wise the car
came with everything.

You've got power seats, power
door locks, power windows,

power top, air conditioning,
automatic climate control.

This car had every luxury
option you could
ever want in a car.
And remember, this is 1964.

This wasn't the '80s or the '90s
when stuff was standard.

You look at the back of the car,
and you see ashtrays with

cigarette lighters in there
because, guess what?
People still smoked back then.

And they also have these
beautiful kind of stainless

steel bezels with these lenses,
so when the front

seats went up, the lights went
on to illuminate where the

passenger was going to
get in and out--

stuff that manufacturers don't
put in cars today because it's

too much money, and they
won't be able to do it.

Cadillac took great pains to
make sure that their car stood

out above the rest-- that they
really did build luxury cars

that made a statement, not
only about the cars

themselves, but about the
people who drove them.

RON DEAN: Yeah, well,
when I first got the
car, it didn't run.
So I had it towed over here.

We got it running, and took
a look at it, and said,
definitely needs some paint.

So we kind of went through it,
to the motor, went through the

bodywork, to paint,
top, upholstery.
That was the first step.

And we painted it lacquer
red at the time.

And I kept that for about 15
years like that, got tired of

it, decided to go to black, took
the motor out again redid

the motor, went through it, and
then got tired of that.
And I wound up with this here.

MIKE MUSTO: So today is a very
exciting day for us here on

"Big Muscle." And let
me tell you why.

Right now we're behind the wheel
of a 1964 Cadillac, not

a car that you would generally
think is, like, well, a muscle
car, so to speak.

But this is not your everyday
'64 Cadillac.

You see, the car that we're
driving right now is, I guess,

like, the epitome of
what a hotrod is.

'64 Cadillac, 19 feet long,
4,600 pounds, with a 468 cubic

inch Chevy big block with
a 671 blower on top.

And we're driving along
the coast, California.

Oh, ladies and gentlemen, if you
want to know what nirvana
is, welcome to "Big Muscle."

What's really cool about
this car is the
visceral impact it makes.

And I mean, now normally, when
you drive, you're basically,

you're looking out, you're
looking over the hood, and

you're really not seeing
anything except a big black
canvas of a hood.

But here you've got
so much going on.

I mean, I can look forward, and
I can see the pulley with

the massive belt of the
blower spinning.

If I put my foot on the
throttle, I can see the

linkage on the carburetors
moving back and forth.

With the top down, I've got the
wind in what's remaining

of my hair, and it's just
a wonderful experience.

Now the butt dyno in this thing
say that this thing has
650 horsepower?
Well, [LAUGH]

I mean, the car definitely
goes when you romp on it.
There's no question.

650 horsepower may sound like
an amazing amount of power,

but the car is 4,600
4,700 pounds.
It's a big, old Cadillac--

lots of steel, lots of chrome,
lot's of stuff in here that
just weighs this baby down.

You guys are going to look and
say, Mike, why aren't both
hands on the wheel?
Well, it's a convertible.

We're doing 60 miles an hour
and just relaxing.

Now, we are also wearing seat
belts, for those of you guys

that are going to look and
be like, why isn't he
wearing a seat belt?

You have to remember, in 1964,
lap belts were standard
equipment in cars.
You can't see it--
there's a lap belt here.

From a breaking standpoint,
Ron has also
upgraded the breaks.

There are front stock brakes,
stock disk brakes up front,

but he's also upgraded the
rears to disk as well.

So the car actually has a
really good pedal feel.
And it's fine.

I mean, you want to hit the
brakes, the car's very

compliant and comes
to a good stop.

The best part is, thanks to this
massive 468 cubic inch

motor and the blower on top, is
that when you whack it, now

you put two hands
on the wheel!

RON DEAN: Everybody
asks me that.
[LAUGH]

But the reason I did it is
because I had a vision, I

guess, of always having a car
with a blown motor in it.

And I figure, well, why
not a Cadillac?

Because you don't see
a lot of them.

And the horsepower was
great for the car,
and it looks good.

And I don't think I could've
made a better choice.

MIKE MUSTO: Driving, generally,
any car from the

1960s, you're generally talking
about a car with a
very slushy ride.

I mean, older shocks, skinny
tires, and it, basically, is
just kind of sloppy ride.

I mean, it's not much different
than any mid-'80s

car from America that
you would buy.

Now, Ron hasn't done that much
to this car aside from adding

some new shocks in the
front and an airbag
suspension in the rear.
Is this is a canyon carver?
Not by any stretch.

It's not what the car
was built for.

I mean, 19 feet long, blower,
convertible this car was built

for exactly what we're doing
now, which is cruising down

the coast on an absolutely
stunning day.

So now when you look at
Ron, what do you see?

Well, you see a guy that's in
his 60s, a guy that's gone

through life, has worked
hard, and he's
always been a hot rodder.

But what would possess a man
to say, I'm going to take a

Cadillac and put, like, a
cartoon flame side on the

side, with the blower
and everything else?

I mean, basically he did
something that very few people
would even dream of doing.

The outside is up badass
carnival ride.

I mean, it's ridiculous
to look at.
And it's fun.

You can't drive by anybody
without them making a comment.

But the interior is bone stock,
and it's wonderful--

the chrome, they gauges,
the skinny
Cadillac steering wheel.

He's got a turbo 400
transmission and Ford 9-inch,

so it's a nice automatic
with over drive.
There's no shifting.

There's crazy linkage that
you have to worry about--

just a good old, solid GM tranny
that you know is going

to last for thousands
of miles.
There's no issues.
There's no bogging.
There's no stumbling.

The car almost runs like a
fuel-injected engine, and it's
a wonderful, wonderful piece.

There's no starting issues, no
stalling issues, no issues

whatsoever that would make you
think that this car is a

really raunchous beast
that can't be
driven on a daily basis.
It absolutely can.

And Ron drives it as
such, which is a
testament to the car.

Man, I've seen cars at car
shows all over the place.
This is what we want, man.

This is the car you
want to film.
This is the car that just--
I don't know.
Four years old again, dude.
It doesn't get better.
Doesn't get better.

RON DEAN: Well, in our
circle of friends, we
don't own small blocks.

They're just not allowed
in our cars.
So we made a decision--

if it's going to be
big, make it big.

MIKE MUSTO: So never in a
million years did I think we'd

feature a Cadillac on "Big
Muscle." I mean, it just
doesn't fit the mold.
These cars are cruisers.

But then I thought about
it, and you know want?

The title of the show is "Big
Muscle," not "Big Muscle Car."

That encompasses everything--
hot rods, pro tours, Cadillacs
with blowers.
I loved this car today.

I had a blast with
this car today.

It made me laugh and giggle
like a four-year-old.

So Ron, thanks for letting
us drive this thing.

And you know, send
us your emails--
drivebigmuscle@gmail.com.

We're going to bring you
more stuff like this.

We're going to continue to
enjoy, beat on it, and show it
to you guys.
So thanks very much.

RON DEAN: How much to
wash the windshield?

MIKE MUSTO: I don't
know, $2.49?

But for you, dad because I like
your face, I'll do it for
you for nothing.

See this is what happens when
you grow up in Brooklyn.

You watch the squeegee
guys your whole life.

If "Big Muscle" doesn't work
out, I've got something to

fall back on, you know
what I mean?

comments.author: David Heitman

comments.text:
My step mother had a '64 Caddy, originally silver metal flake, beautiful 
car, but she had it painted yellow. Her brother, James Hylton, was a NASCAR 
rookie in '66, and it was yellow, so she had her Caddy painted the same 
color. Just recently I found out that the reason his race car was yellow, 
was because of budget considerations. It was surplus school bus paint. So 
she had that Caddy painted school bus yellow. Oh the humanity! (BTW James 
Hylton just retired from ARCA as a driver. He still enters cars in ARCA, 
but with younger drivers).﻿

comments.author: twotailedavenger

comments.text:
This is an interesting video, but this guy doesn't know jack about '64 
Cadillacs or the nature of cars in the mid 60s. He should either have done 
some research or talked about what he knows. The extent of his ignorance is 
ridiculous, modern Cadillacs had bucket seat options from 1959, dash was 
chrome plated steel, not stainless, door trim was chromed pot metal, 
turbo-hydramatic new for '64 was a 3 speed with torque converter, Cadillac 
had the world's first automatic climate control air conditioning system in 
1964. (Cadillac also had the world's first uniform manufacturing 
specifications, electric self start, laminated safety glass, tilting beam 
headlamps, mass produced V8 engine, synchromesh 3 speed manual 
transmission, to mention a few). In 1964 Mercedes cars were very rare 
sights in the US, and the stock Cadillac 429 cu in engine was a torque 
monster and a refinement of the original, revolutionary 331 cu in (first 
mass produced OHV high- compression V-8) 1949 engine which was legendary in 
early '50s racing applications. Ed Cole who led the GM team that designed 
the '49 Cadillac V8 also designed the small block Chevy engine that debuted 
in 1955.﻿

comments.text:
Cadillac with a generic Chevy motor in it.  Yeah, that's awesome...not.  
And it doesn't weigh 4600lbs, either.  It weighs 3800; I own one.  Oh, and 
no, the front brakes were not disc stock.  All 64's came with 4 wheel 
drums...and when did Turbo 400's turn into "overdrive" transmissions?﻿
comments.author: FMChimera

comments.text:

first in gm..??? i think it was an option untill 65-66. I could be wrong. 
Im a buick/olds/pontiac kinda guy... dont know much about the caddy 
background
comments.author: Mike Hunt

comments.text:
+plaqueconspiracy It was weighed on a grain scale and a local freight 
company scale at different times.  Within 75lbs of each other.  Of course 
weight is subjective when the parameters are so ill-defined, too:  
Driver/no driver?  Full fuel/no fuel?  Spare/no spare?  In this case it was 
no driver, little fuel, no spare, 17" aluminum wheels with 255/50 Kumho 
tires.  If the "factory weight" includes spare tire, full tank and a driver 
then that accts for most(if not all) of the weight difference right there.
comments.author: FMChimera

comments.text:

me.  Until then, why would I continue to argue with someone silly enough to 
define their online persona by a lowly BMW?

comments.text:
My mother started driving Cadillac's when I was a kid in 1967! Her first 
was a Coupe'Deville convertible. Burgundy body with tan top and interiors! 
So many memories! Cadillac Forever!
comments.author: SouthernWasp

comments.text:
In 1964 when it was incredible if your car had air-con and a lighter, 
something with all of those optional features that was that comfortable and 
built that well would be the equivalent of buying a Maybach today. It was a 
different age and while today, Cadillacs are either driven by pimps or 
pensioners, at one point they were the standard for luxury.
comments.author: Adam Parker

comments.text: Totally agree.

That is something you don't see every day. A nice build, a nice car, 
straight body with a nice paint job. Flames look good on it without being 
too over powering. Sounds good, but the mufflers have too much blap to 
them. Awesome job on the build.

comments.text:
wut? That car doesn't have any wood trim on it. Luxury cars always have and 
always will be large cars. Look at luxury cars from the 1920s and 30s. The 
Bugatti Royale, Rolls Royce Phantom, Duesenberg Model J. The 1950s, 50s, 
and 70s Cadillac Eldorados, Fleetwoods, Chysler Imperial, Lincoln 
Continental, Mercedes Benz 600. Now you have huge BMW 7 series, Bentley 
Mulsanne, Audi A8, Cadillac XTS, Mercedes S-class, Maybachs, etc.
